elements.label: To do: Choose a lead maternity carer

elements.content:
As soon as you know you're pregnant, you need to choose a lead maternity carer (LMC). LMCs are:

  • registered midwives
  • obstetricians (doctors who specialise in pregnancy and childbirth)
  • family doctors who provide maternity care.

If you're a New Zealand citizen or permanent resident, you'll get free or subsidised maternity care unless you choose an obstetrician.

elements.label: Who can get free or subsidised maternity care
elements.content:
You'll get free or subsidised maternity care if you, or your partner by de facto relationship, marriage or civil union, is:

  • a New Zealand citizen or permanent resident
  • an Australian citizen or permanent resident who's lived, or intends to live, in New Zealand for 2 years or more
  • under 17 and your parent or guardian is eligible
  • a work visa holder who's eligible to be here for 2 years or more
  • an interim visa holder who was eligible just before you got the interim visa
  • a New Zealand Aid Programme student
  • a commonwealth scholarship student
  • a refugee or protected person, or in the process of applying or appealing for refugee or protection status
  • a victim of people trafficking.

elements.label: What an LMC does
elements.content:
Your LMC will:

  • provide care throughout your pregnancy
  • provide information about choices you can make, eg where to give birth
  • be with you when you give birth
  • provide care to you and your baby for 4-6 weeks after the birth
  • refer you or your baby to a specialist, if needed.

Talk to your doctor or nurse about choosing an LMC, or visit the Find a Midwife website to search for registered midwives in your area.

You can get screening and tests to check the health of you and your baby at different stages of your pregnancy. You may need to pay for some screening and tests. Talk to your lead maternity carer about what kind of screening and tests you should have.

The first test you can get is a free blood test. Your doctor or lead maternity carer can refer you for this test.

elements.label: First antenatal blood test link to blood test facts sheet
Further screening
elements.content:
Further screening

You'll be told about other screening you can choose to get during your pregnancy, including screening for Down Syndrome and other conditions.

You may be charged for some of these scans.

elements.label: Pregnancy screening and tests link to screening

elements.content:
You can get advice and help to protect your health while you're pregnant — including:

  • getting the right nutrients
  • eating and handling food that is safe for your baby
  • quitting smoking, drinking alcohol and doing drugs
  • getting immunised for influenza (flu) and whooping cough.

elements.label: Healthed link to eating healthy during preganancy
elements.linkText: What to eat for a healthy pregnancy

elements.label: MPI link to food safety during pregnancy
health.govt link to vitamine advice
elements.linkText: Getting folic acid, iodine and Vitamin D

elements.label: link to quit.org to quit smoking
Link to alcaholdrughelp.org
elements.linkText: Help to quit alcohol and drugs

elements.label: If you have morning sickness
elements.content:
You can also get advice to cope with morning sickness and to know when to ask for help.

Coping with morning sickness

elements.label: Check what financial help you can get
To do: Check what financial help you can get

elements.content: Working for Families is a payment to help parents with the costs of raising children. It's made up of 4 tax credits — you might be eligible for 1 or more of these.

elements.label: Link to IRD to apply for WFF
Parental tax credit
elements.content:
What it is

A payment of up to $220 a week for 10 weeks after your baby is born. You can't get it if you receive paid parental leave or a WINZ benefit.

Who can get it

Families with a newborn who don't get:

  • paid parental leave
  • a Work and Income benefit (even if it is suspended)
  • NZ Superannuation
  • a Veteran's Pension
  • a student allowance, or
  • ACC payments (unless you get them for less than 3 months).

How much you get

The payment is for up to $220 a week. How much you might get depends on:

  • your family income before tax
  • how many dependent children you have
  • the age of these children
  • how many newborn babies you have.

Estimating your family income

Estimate your entitlement

You apply for all Working for Families tax credits at the same time.

How to apply

elements.label: Family tax credit
elements.content:
What it is

Family tax credit is a payment of up to $101 per child for families with dependent children.

Who can get it

You might get a family tax credit if you have:And your family income before tax is less than:
1 child$57,500
2 children$71,000
3 children$86,000
4 children$101,000
5 children$116,000

You can't get a family tax credit for child(ren) who you already receive a foster care allowance, orphan's benefit or unsupported child's benefit for.

How much you get

The amount of family tax credit depends on:

  • your annual family income
  • the number of dependent children in your care
  • the age of these children.

Estimating your family income

Estimate your entitlement

You apply for all Working for Families tax credits at the same time.

How to apply

elements.label: Minimum family tax credit
elements.content:
What it is

Minimum family tax credit tops up the annual income for families with dependent children who earn less than $23,764 after tax.

Who can get it

You can get minimum family tax credit if you earn less than $23,764 a year and work for at least:

  • 30 hours each week (for a couple), or
  • 20 hours each week as a single parent.

How much you get

The amount you get depends on how much you earn. Your payment will top up your annual salary or wages to $23,764 after tax.

Estimating your family income

Estimate your entitlement

You apply for all Working for Families tax credits at the same time.

How to apply

elements.label: In-work tax credit
elements.content:
What it is

In-work tax credit is a payment for families who are in paid work.

Who can get it

To qualify for in-work tax credit you must be in paid work for at least:

  • 30 hours each week as a couple, eg one person works 5 hours and the other works 25 hours, or
  • 20 hours each week as a single parent.

You must receive one of these types of income from that work:

  • a salary or wage
  • a shareholder salary, if you are a shareholder-employee in a close company, or
  • business income.

If you occasionally work the required hours, you can let IRD know and get paid for the weeks you qualify.

How much you get

The amount of in-work tax credit depends on:

  • your annual family income before tax
  • the number of dependent children in your care.

If you have 1, 2 or 3 children the maximum you can receive is:

  • $72 a week, or
  • $145 a fortnight.

If you have more than 3 children, for each additional child a further:

  • $15 a week, or
  • $30 a fortnight.

Estimating your family income

Estimate your entitlement

You apply for all Working for Families tax credits at the same time.

How to apply
Work and Income offers an accommodation supplement to help with the costs of rent, board and home ownership. You might be able to get it if your family income is less than $?.

elements.label: Accommodation supplement
elements.content:
What it is

An accommodation supplement is a payment to help with accommodation costs.

Who can get it

You might get an accommodation supplement if you:

  • have accommodation costs
  • are aged 16 or over
  • are a New Zealand citizen or permanent resident
  • normally live in New Zealand and intend to stay here
  • aren't paying rent for a Housing NZ or other social housing property.

It also depends on:

  • how much you and your spouse or partner earn
  • any money or assets you and your spouse or partner have.

How much you get

How much you might get depends on:

  • your income
  • your assets
  • your accommodation costs
  • your family circumstances
  • where you live.

Accommodation Supplement calculator (Working for Families website)

More about accommodation supplement
Community Services Cards help New Zealanders on a low to middle income with cheaper health costs.

elements.label: Community Services Cards
elements.content:
What it is

Community Services Cards reduce the costs of some healthcare services, including:

  • full-priced prescriptions
  • visits to after-hours doctors or a doctor who's not your usual doctor
  • glasses for children under 16
  • emergency dental treatment.

Who can get it

You might be able to get a Community Services Card if you're:

  • 18 years old or over
  • on a low to middle-income
  • a New Zealand citizen or permanent resident
  • normally live in New Zealand and intend to stay here.

How much you get

You'll still pay for healthcare services, but the card gives you a discount on the costs you'd otherwise pay.

More about the Community Services Card

Sole Parent Support helps single parents and caregivers of dependent children get ready for future work, find part-time work and provides financial support with a payment of up to $325.98 a week after tax.

elements.label: Sole Parent Support payment
elements.content:
What it is

Help for single parents and caregivers of dependent children aged under 14.

Who can get it

You may get Sole Parent Support if you are:

  • aged 19 or older
  • not in a relationship
  • without adequate financial support
  • a New Zealand citizen or permanent resident who has been here for at least 2 years at any time since becoming a citizen or permanent resident, and who normally lives here.

If you meet all the above criteria except for the one about how long you’ve lived in New Zealand, speak to Work and Income.

Only one parent or caregiver can get Sole Parent Support. Shared care of your child could affect your payments.

How much you get

Sole parent support:

  • helps you get ready for future work (if your youngest child is under 3)
  • supports you to find part-time work (if your youngest child is 3 or older)
  • provides financial help through a weekly payment of up to $325.98 a week after tax
  • might help you with education and training.

More about Sole Parent Support

elements.label: Calculating child support
elements.content:
If you and your partner aren't together anymore, you might be eligible for, or need to pay child support.

More about child support

Work out how much you should get or how much you have to pay.

IRD child support calculator

elements.label: To do: Check if you can get help paying for childcare

elements.content: If you have a dependant child who's under 5 (or under 6 if you get a Child Disability Allowance for them), you might be able to get a childcare subsidy if they're in approved care for at least 3 hours a week.

elements.label: To do: Check if you can get help paying for childcare

elements.content: If you have a dependant child who's under 5 (or under 6 if you get a Child Disability Allowance for them), you might be able to get a childcare subsidy if they're in approved care for at least 3 hours a week.

elements.label: To do: Check what parental leave you can get

elements.content: The government provides a payment for eligible new parents and caregivers of up to $527.72 a week before tax, for 18 weeks.

elements.label: Who can get it
elements.content:
Expectant mothers and other primary carers who have worked (either as an employee or self-employed) for an average of 10 hours or more per week for at least any 26 of the 52 weeks up to your due date or date the child comes into your care.

Mothers can choose to transfer some or all of their paid leave entitlement to their spouse or partner.

You can only get parental leave payments while you aren’t working. You might also be entitled to unpaid parental leave of up to 52 weeks (including the 18 weeks you receive a payment for).

More about parental leave

If you don't meet the criteria for paid parental leave, you might be able to get the Working for Families parental tax credit.

More about parental tax credit

elements.label: How much you get
elements.content:
PPL payments equal your normal pay up to a current maximum of $527.72 a week before tax. The minimum payment is $152.50 each week before tax.

It's paid into your bank account fortnightly.
Parental leave is leave you can take from work to care for your new child. Apply for parental leave from your employer in writing, at least 3 months before your baby is due.

elements.label: When you're eligible and what you'll get
elements.content:
To be eligible for parental leave, you must have worked for the same employer for at least 10 hours a week for the 6 months before your baby's due date (or the date you become permanently responsible for the care of a child under 6).

If you've worked for them:

  • for more than 6 months, but less than 12 months, you'll get:
    • 18 weeks of government-paid parental leave, and
    • 8 weeks unpaid leave as well, up to 26 weeks' leave in total
  • for more than 12 months, you'll get:
    • 18 weeks of government-paid parental leave
    • up to 36 weeks' unpaid leave after the paid leave ends. Your job must be kept open for you for 52 weeks.

You can transfer some or all of your parental leave entitlements to your partner, as long as they meet the same eligibility criteria.

Taking parental leave

elements.label: Immunisations for whooping cough and influenza (flu) for pregnant women

elements.content:
Immunisations help protect you and your baby before and after birth. While you're pregnant, you can get:

  • flu immunisation at any stage during your pregnancy, and for free during the flu season — usually early March to late July or August
  • free whooping cough immunisation between 28 and 38 weeks of your pregnancy.

Talk to your doctor, nurse or lead maternity carer about getting immunised.

Immunisations while pregnant

elements.label: Link to health.govt about immunisation for pregnant women

elements.content:
Antenatal classes teach you about pregnancy, labour, birth, breastfeeding and looking after a young baby. You can get limited free classes through most District Health Boards, or pay for classes with private providers.

[District Health Boards]

Free classes fill up quickly, so book by the time you're 16 weeks pregnant to get your preferred class. You don't need to attend antenatal classes until you or your partner are about 26 weeks pregnant.

Talk to your LMC about antenatal classes in your area.

elements.label: Enrol your child with a family doctor and a dentist

elements.content:
As soon as your baby is born, enrol them with a family doctor if they are not already enrolled. You can enrol your child for free dental care at the same time.

To find a family doctor, talk to:

  • your midwife or obstetrician
  • your Well Child Tamariki Ora nurse.

Find doctors and general practices in your area

Your child will get:

  • free immunisations at 6 weeks, 3 months and 5 months
  • free visits, prescriptions for most medicines, and free after-hours care until they turn 13.

The Ministry of Health recommends that you breastfeed your baby. Breastfeeding:

  • provides all the food your baby needs for their first 6 months
  • can help to protect your baby from sickness and cot death
  • helps your baby feel safe.

Breastfeeding can be hard at first. Your lead maternity carer will help you prepare for breastfeeding and can help you breastfeed once your baby is born.

How to breastfeed

elements.label: If you can't breastfeed
elements.content:
You can use donated milk or infant formula. Infant formula is the only suitable breast milk substitute for babies under 1.

Donated breast milk

Formula feeding

elements.label: To do: Get a car seat ready

elements.content:
If you have a car, you'll need a car seat before you can leave hospital with your baby.

You can rent or buy an infant capsule, or a car seat that's suitable for newborn babies.

You can buy or hire car seats from Plunket's car seat service (until the end of 2016) or large baby gear providers.

If you're buying a car seat, check that it fits in your car first. If you're buying second hand, check that it:

  • has a safety standard label and an instruction book
  • hasn’t been in a crash
  • has no fraying on the harness straps
  • has a working buckle with no rust
  • isn't past its expiry date.

elements.label: To do: Choose a Well Child Tamariki Ora provider
What you'll get
elements.content:
When you join Well Child Tamariki Ora you'll get:

  • free health checks for you and your baby from a nurse or registered health practitioner
  • information on breastfeeding and safe sleep practices
  • information on protecting and improving your child's health and development
  • a book to track your child's progress and health record.

Well Child Tamariki Ora visits

Children under 18 get free vaccinations against 12 diseases from their family doctor or nurse. Your baby should be immunised at:

  • 6 weeks
  • 3 months
  • 5 months.

New Zealand Immunisation Schedule

When your baby is 6 weeks old, take them to your doctor to get their first immunisation.

If you're enrolled with a doctor, they'll contact you to make an appointment. If you haven't heard from your doctor or you need to enrol, talk to your midwife or obstetrician.

Postnatal depression affects some parents in the first year after having a baby.

Signs

It's normal to feel down, unsure or anxious in the first few weeks after having your baby. If these feelings last longer than a few weeks, they could be signs of postnatal depression.

Signs include:

  • crying a lot
  • feeling hopeless, alone or guilty
  • feeling angry
  • not sleeping
  • feeling that you're a bad parent
  • thoughts of harming you or your baby.

Getting help

Postnatal depression is treated with medication and therapy. Talk to your:

  • midwife or obstetrician
  • Well Child Tamariki Ora nurse
  • family doctor or practice nurse.

You can also call the depression or Plunket advice lines:

  • Depression freephone: 0800 111 757
  • Plunketline freephone: 0800 933 922

elements.label: To do: Register the birth
To do: Apply for an IRD number for your child
To do: Add your child to your Working for Families application
To do: If you're on a benefit, tell Work and Income your child has been born

elements.content: You can register your baby's birth (and order a birth certificate) online. You need to register it within 2 months of the birth. It's free to register the birth, but you have to pay for a birth certificate.

When you register your baby, you can also apply for:

  • your baby’s birth certificate — this costs $26.50 or $39.80 for a pack including a decorative birth certificate
  • an IRD number for your baby — you’ll need this to claim Working for Families payments for the child, or to open a KiwiSaver or bank account in their name.

Registering your new baby and getting a birth certificate

Plunket provides free classes about child development and parenting from birth until your child starts school.

Plunket Parenting Education Programme

Find a Plunket centre

The Family Services Directory lists family services and support in your area. You can also call Healthline or Plunketline for advice about your child's health and development.

Family Services Directory

Healthline freephone: 0800 611 116

Plunketline freephone: 0800 933 922
When your baby is 3 months old, take them to your doctor to get their second set of immunisations.

elements.label: Check what financial help you can get

More about accommodation supplement
Community Services Cards help New Zealanders on a low to middle income with cheaper health costs.

elements.label: Community Services Cards
elements.content:
What it is

Community Services Cards reduce the costs of some healthcare services, including:

  • full-priced prescriptions
  • visits to after-hours doctors or a doctor who's not your usual doctor
  • glasses for children under 16
  • emergency dental treatment.

Who can get it

You might be able to get a Community Services Card if you're:

  • 18 years old or over
  • on a low to middle-income
  • a New Zealand citizen or permanent resident
  • normally live in New Zealand and intend to stay here.

How much you get

You'll still pay for healthcare services, but the card gives you a discount on the costs you'd otherwise pay.

More about the Community Services Card

Sole Parent Support helps single parents and caregivers of dependent children get ready for future work, find part-time work and provides financial support with a payment of up to $325.98 a week after tax.

elements.label: Sole Parent Support payment
elements.content:
What it is

Help for single parents and caregivers of dependent children aged under 14.

Who can get it

You may get Sole Parent Support if you are:

  • aged 19 or older
  • not in a relationship
  • without adequate financial support
  • a New Zealand citizen or permanent resident who has been here for at least 2 years at any time since becoming a citizen or permanent resident, and who normally lives here.

If you meet all the above criteria except for the one about how long you’ve lived in New Zealand, speak to Work and Income.

Only one parent or caregiver can get Sole Parent Support. Shared care of your child could affect your payments.

How much you get

Sole parent support:

  • helps you get ready for future work (if your youngest child is under 3)
  • supports you to find part-time work (if your youngest child is 3 or older)
  • provides financial help through a weekly payment of up to $325.98 a week after tax
  • might help you with education and training.

More about Sole Parent Support

elements.label: Calculating child support
elements.content:
If you and your partner aren't together anymore, you might be eligible for, or need to pay child support.

More about child support

Work out how much you should get or how much you have to pay.

IRD child support calculator
When your baby is 5 months old, take them to your doctor to get their third set of immunisations.

elements.label: To do: If you receive Working for Families payments, let IRD know if your income changes

elements.content:
You have to give 21 days notice:

  • before you return to work
  • if you decide not to go back to work.

Returning to work when your parental leave ends

Your boss needs to provide a place for you to have a break and breastfeed or express. Breastfeeding or expressing breaks are taken on top of your rest and meal breaks and are unpaid unless otherwise agreed.

elements.label: To do: Check if you can get help paying for childcare

elements.content: If you have a dependant child who's under 5 (or under 6 if you get a Child Disability Allowance for them), you might be able to get a childcare subsidy if they're in approved care for at least 3 hours a week.

Babies and children under 16 must travel on their own passports. A parent or legal guardian has to give consent for the passport to be issued.

You can't apply for a child's passport online. You can complete an application form on-screen but you'll need to print it off, sign it and either send or take it into the Department of Internal Affairs.

It costs NZ$105 and takes up to 10 working days for the passport to be issued (unless you need the passport urgently, or are applying from overseas).

elements.label: Link to passports child passports page
elements.linkText: Apply for a child's first passport

tags.description: Is used to tag the additional topics which aren't covered in the life event map.

tags.description: Used to tag content about the site such as the privacy statement and copyright.

tags.title: Non chronological
tags.description: Example to show health content out of context

elements.content:
Losing a baby is very hard, and unfortunately quite common — around 1 in 5 pregnancies end in miscarriage.

Miscarriage is most common in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy, but can happen up until 20 weeks. Losing a baby after 20 weeks is a stillbirth, which is much less common than miscarriage — it affects about 1 in every 200 pregnancies.

Miscarriage and stillbirth

If you're worried that something might be wrong, speak to your LMC.

Danger signs during pregnancy

If you've lost your baby and need support, there are several organisations you can speak to.

Sands New Zealand
Miscarriage Support
Skylight

If you or someone else is in immediate danger, call 111 now.

Being pregnant and having a baby can be stressful. It's a time when you can be more vulnerable to family violence.

Family violence and young families

If you feel unsafe at home, speak to your LMC, doctor or someone you trust to help. There is free support available.

Services and support for victims of domestic violence

Postnatal depression affects some parents in the first year after having a baby.

Signs

It's normal to feel down, unsure or anxious in the first few weeks after having your baby. If these feelings last longer than a few weeks, they could be signs of postnatal depression.

Signs include:

  • crying a lot
  • feeling hopeless, alone or guilty
  • feeling angry
  • not sleeping
  • feeling that you're a bad parent
  • thoughts of harming you or your baby.

Getting help

Postnatal depression is treated with medication and therapy. Talk to your:

  • midwife or obstetrician
  • Well Child Tamariki Ora nurse
  • family doctor or practice nurse.

You can also call the depression or Plunket advice lines:

  • Depression freephone: 0800 111 757
  • Plunketline freephone: 0800 933 922

All babies cry, and sometimes it's hard to work out why they're crying. To help stop your baby crying, you could try:

  • feeding your baby
  • holding him or her close, or using a sling or front pack
  • rocking baby in the pram or going out for a walk or drive
  • playing some music or white noise.

If your baby’s cry is unusual — for example, piercing and high pitched — take them to a doctor straight away.

It can be really hard when your baby keeps crying and you don't know why and nothing you do helps. Sometimes it's best to put your baby down gently in a safe place, walk away and take a break.

Coping with a crying baby

Never, ever shake a baby. Never leave a baby alone with anyone who might lose control. A single moment of losing control can damage a baby forever. Babies can die if they're shaken.

If you ever think your baby has been hurt, call 111.

Shaken baby syndrome

Abortion is legal in New Zealand and free to any pregnant NZ resident.

If you're unsure about your pregnancy and considering an abortion, start by speaking to a doctor or Family Planning. They can refer you to a health service that provides abortions. Abortion providers give free, unbiased counselling to help you make a decision about whether to terminate or to continue with your pregnancy.

Depending on where you live, you may need to travel to an abortion service.

To get an abortion, you need 2 doctors to certify that continuing the pregnancy would result in serious danger to your mental or physical health.

There are 2 abortion options:

  • early medical abortion is an option if you're less than 9 weeks pregnant
  • surgical abortion is an option up to 20 weeks of pregnancy. Only 4 places in NZ do abortions if you're more than 12 weeks pregnant — if you're more than 16 weeks pregnant, it's likely to be done under general anaesthetic.

Find an abortion provider

If you're more than 20 weeks pregnant, there are stricter criteria to be eligible for an abortion. You might have to travel to Australia for the procedure.

Abortion — Family Planning
Abortion services in New Zealand

An adoption social worker can help you decide whether adoption is right for you and your baby. They will discuss all the options with you and guide you through the process.

Placing a child for adoption

How it works

You choose the family who will adopt your baby.

You'll be given profiles of different families who are hoping to adopt a child. Once you choose a family your social worker will let them know. You can meet them if you want to.

Most new adoptions in New Zealand are open adoptions. The birth parents and adoptive parents know each other by name and often agree to ongoing contact.

Once an adoptive child turns 20, they’re entitled to information about their adoption. This can include their pre-adoptive birth certificate and other information held by Adoption Services.

Whāngai is the Māori tradition of children being raised by someone other than their birth parents — usually by whānau or extended family.

How it works

It can be a short-term, long-term or permanent arrangement. In most cases whāngai takes place at birth, but it can also involve older children.

Whāngai is informal. A whāngai placement is arranged directly between the birth parents and the mātua whāngai (the family who will raise the child). Child, Youth and Family do not need to be involved and the birth parents are still the child’s legal guardians.

A whāngai child usually knows its birth parents and has an ongoing relationship with them.

Whāngai - customary fostering and adoption and other information held by Adoption Services.

Unless indicated below, or on specific items or collections of content:

any copyright in content on Bundle is owned by the New Zealand Crown; and

the Department of Internal Affairs (on behalf of the Crown) licenses you to copy, distribute and adapt that content in accordance with the Creative Commons Attribution (CC-BY) 3.0 New Zealand Licence. 

You should understand the terms of the licence, which requires that you attribute the content to the Crown and the Bundle website.

CC-BY 3.0 NZ license terms 

Exceptions

Copyright in photographs on Bundle is not owned, or licensed to you, by the Crown. Unless otherwise stated in relation to specific photographs, you cannot copy, distribute or adapt any photograph without the agreement of the copyright owner.

The New Zealand Government logo, Coat of Arms and other logos, emblems and trade marks on Bundle are protected by law.  You must not copy or use logo, emblem or trade mark without express permission and compliance with applicable laws.

Personal information submitted to the Department of Internal Affairs (Internal Affairs)

Internal Affairs collects personal information in order to provide you with a variety of services (for example, in the provision of passports and birth certificates). You may browse and access information contained within this website without providing personal information, however, where you voluntarily provide personal information (e.g. through online forms or applications) we will keep and use that information for the purpose with which it was collected. If you want further information about Internal Affairs’ general privacy policy use the following link:
Learn more about general privacy issues and personal information related to the Internal Affairs’ services.

Much of the personal information we collect on this site relates to births, deaths, marriages, and civil union services. If you want further information about births, deaths and marriages privacy policy please follow this link.
Learn more about privacy issues and personal information related to births, deaths and marriages.

Additional personal information collected on Bundle

Scope

This section applies to personal information collected by Internal Affairs to develop a customer profile for individuals using the Bundle site.

Personal Information

The Bundle site provides information about services associated to having a child. The site is operated by Internal Affairs on behalf of agencies involved in this service, including Inland Revenue and the Ministries of Health and Social Development.   
By collecting personal information about you to develop a customer profile we can provide information more relevant to your situation. 

You can provide the following information about your situation:
  • The city/town/place you reside
  • your age
  • your relationship to the baby
  • the gender of the baby if known
  • the expected due date of the baby
  • the baby’s name
  • your personal income bracket
  • your household income bracket
  • number of dependent children in your care
  • your New Zealand residency status.
This information will only be used to customise the service information displayed on this site and to enable you to self-assess eligibility for services.  The information you provide for the customer profile will not be passed on or used by a service providing agency to determine your eligibility for services.     

Your choices

You can choose what personal information to provide in your customer profile. The more information you provide the better the information about services on this site will be customised to your circumstances.
Any personal information you choose to provide for the customer profile may be deleted any time at your discretion.   

Information storage

Information provided for the customer profile is stored on behalf of Internal Affairs in a cloud solution delivered by a supplier certified by the Government Chief Information Officer. This arrangement uses the all-of-government Infrastructure as a Service. If you want further information about the Infrastructure as a Service please use the following link:
Learn more about Infrastructure as a Service
Internal Affairs retains responsibility for the personal information collected to develop the customer profile.

Feedback, more information or corrections

If you wish to find out more information on what data is collected and how it is used, view or correct any of your personal information held by the department, or you have concerns about the personal information we hold on you, please feel free to contact us at:
The Privacy Officer
Department of Internal Affairs
PO Box 805
Wellington 6143
New Zealand
Phone: (04) 495 7200
Email: privacy@dia.govt.nz 
If you are not satisfied with our response to your concern, you have the right to contact the Privacy Commissioner:
Office of the Privacy Commissioner
PO Box 10-094
Wellington, New Zealand
Phone: +64-4-474 7590
Enquiries Line (from Auckland): 302 8680
Enquiries Line (from outside Auckland): 0800 803 909
Fax: +64-4-474 7595
Email: enquiries@privacy.org.nz
 

Statistical information collected

The Department may collect statistical information about your visit to help us improve the Site. This information is aggregated and does not identify individuals. It includes:
your IP address;
the search terms you used;
the pages you accessed on our site and the links you clicked on;
the date and time you visited the site;
the referring site (if any) through which you clicked through to this site;
your operating system (e.g., Windows 7, Mac OSX);
the type of web browser you use (e.g. Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox); and
other incidental matters such as screen resolution, the release of your installed Flash version and the language setting of your browser.

This statistical information can be viewed by site administrators and certain other Department staff. It may also be shared with other government agencies.
Data tracking used by Bundle
This website uses cookies to record information about user behaviour. A cookie is a piece of code that creates a file on your computer to track the pages that you view on our website.
We use Piwik to collect and analyse traffic on our site. The goal of the analytics is to provide user activity insight so that we may provide you with a better web service.
This information is collected for traffic analysis and site usage only and cannot be used to identify individuals or any personal information. The data is collected and stored on the Bundle server and accessed only by authorised staff. We do not share this information with any other agency, organisation or corporate entity.
Your web browser must be able to accept cookies to use Bundle
You may turn off cookies at any time. Most browsers have a feature that allows the user to refuse cookies or issues a warning when cookies are being sent - check your browser's "Help". Turning off cookies will not affect your ability to use this site, with the exception of the Online Passport Service.
If you have any questions, please email: webmaster@dia.govt.nz
Security
The Department has procedures in place to prevent loss, unlawful access, use, modification, disclosure or other misuse of your information, consistent with good practice and as required by relevant law and policy. Particular care has been taken to ensure that only certain people with specific roles and authorised access levels are able to view your identity and transaction-related information.
Linking to Bundle
You are welcome to link to our site but please follow our linking guidelines below.
When someone clicks on a www.govt.nz/bundle (or https://bundle.services.govt.nz) link on your website, they must view the site full screen, not within a frame. Using frames to display www.govt.nz/bundle (or https://bundle.services.govt.nz) is not permitted.
You or your website must not misrepresent your relationship with www.govt.nz/bundle (or https://bundle.services.govt.nz), or refer to www.govt.nz/bundle (or https://bundle.services.govt.nz) as a ‘partner site’ unless you have express and written permission to do so.
For further information, email webmaster@dia.govt.nz.
